awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Massive Database to Accelerate Data Science Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) programs. The project funds construction of DataMountain, a massive database cluster for high performance computing at the University of Vermont (UVM). The large-memory machine will enhance the Vermont Advanced Computing Core, a virtual laboratory supporting the research of over 500 scientists in the state of Vermont.  With so many fields transitioning from data-scarce to data-rich environments, many important research areas will benefit from this new machine including research into addiction, mental illness, climate change, drug discovery, food systems, and the spread of online misinformation. DataMountain will allow for fast access to enormous datasets, supporting several projects that require computational power and speed to effectively analyze, describe, and explain rapidly growing datasets.

DataMountain will increase by nearly two orders of magnitude the largest random access memory machine available for computational research at UVM, accelerating large-scale data-driven research requiring rapid reading and writing, and facilitating a broad and diverse set of important scientific investigations not currently possible given the existing hardware. It will also enhance the functionality of the high performance computing clusters BlueMoon and DeepGreen, which are dedicated to parallel processing and machine learning respectively. For example, the machine will allow for interactive access to over 50 terabytes of social media data through http://storywrangling.org and http://hedonometer.org for timely analysis of changes related to the COVID-19 pandemic in population-scale physical and mental health data. In addition, DataMountain will allow for massive increases in the spatial and temporal resolution of computational chemistry simulations being performed for data-driven design of next-generation antimicrobial peptides to combat antibiotic resistance. DataMountain will also enable exploration of petabytes of fMRI, genetic, task performance, and survey data associated with 10,000 adolescents across the United States over the next decade. In addition, the machine will accelerate research using unmanned aerial surveillance imaging for tree canopy assessments, facilitate network science modeling of agricultural diversity of crops and nutritional outcomes globally, and help quantify the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on food insecurity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded DataMountain, a massive database cluster for high performance computing at the University of Vermont (UVM). The large-memory machine (64TB RAM) is hosted at the Vermont Advanced Computing Center (VACC), a virtual laboratory supporting the research of over 500 scientists in the state of Vermont. With so many fields transitioning from data-scarce to data-rich environments, many important projects in the state are benefitting from this new machine including research into addiction, mental illness, climate change, drug discovery, food systems, and the spread of online misinformation and disinformation. DataMountain is the largest memory machine in Vermont, enabling fast access to enormous datasets, supporting several projects that require computational power and speed to effectively analyze, describe, and explain rapidly growing datasets. DataMountain has also enhanced the functionality of the high performance computing clusters BlueMoon and DeepGreen, which are dedicated to parallel processing and machine learning respectively. 


DataMountain has transformed the hypothesis generation process for dozens of faculty and students at UVM by making it possible to execute real-time queries of very large datasets including our collection of 200 billion public tweets (a random 10% of those posted between 2008 and 2023). Since Twitter's API was functionally disabled in 2023, we've begun working with Wikipedia and Gallup to aggregate alternative sources of publically available information reflecting collective opinion and emotion. Using a Mongo database installed on the MRI funded machine, computational social scientists in geography, anthropology, public health, and linguistics are working with these datasets to answer questions from their disciplines. Traditionally, work in the social sciences is performed on small sample sizes due to the cost of data collection. DataMountain is allowing Vermont researchers interactive access to over 50 terabytes of social media data, supporting dashboards and APIs for computational social science through http://storywrangling.org and http://hedonometer.org as well as ongoing work with Gallup to explore the relationship between social media derived estimates of well-being and their surveyed world poll data. Ongoing efforts to make data such as that described above more accessible to scholars less commonly represented in high-performance computing environments is leading to exciting cross-disciplinary work.


In more traditional examples of high-performance computing work, the VACC is supporting an international team that recently built a `connectome' atlas, or a neuronal mapping of the adult fruit fly brain, research that fundamentally changes what is possible with respect to connecting theory, modeling, and experiments in neuroscience. Other scientists are using the cluster to develop artificial intelligence methods that design `xenobots', autonomous living robots composed entirely of biological rather than technological components. Computational designs evolved on the cluster and found to be successful at a task such as locomotion are then stitched together, carefully, by hand in the lab using frog stem cells. The team recently announced the remarkable finding that these living robots can kinematically self-replicate. Finally, the cluster supports analysis of the functional magnetic resonance imaging data produced by the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) study of more than 10,000 participants between the ages of 10 and 20. The imaging datasets associated with each participant are enormous, and the VACC has enabled machine learning scientists working on the project to explore much larger training data for their models using this infrastructure.
